questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the Philadelphia chromosome?

choices.text: Balanced translocation between long arms of chromosome 9 and 22
Balanced translocation between short arms of chromosome 9 and 22
Unbalanced translocation between long arms of chromosome 9 and 22
Unbalanced translocation between short arms of chromosome 9 and 22

questions.solution: Correct answer is a: Balanced translocation between long arms of chromosome 9 and 22

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about CML?

choices.text: Reciprocal exchange between breakpoint Cluster Region gene on chromosome 22, ABL1 gene on chromosome 9
Reciprocal exchange between breakpoint Cluster Region gene on chromosome 9, ABL1 gene on chromosome 22
Non-reciprocal exchange between breakpoint Cluster Region gene on chromosome 22, ABL1 gene on chromosome 9
Non-reciprocal exchange between breakpoint Cluster Region gene on chromosome 9, ABL1 gene on chromosome 22

questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Reciprocal exchange between breakpoint Cluster Region gene on chromosome 22, ABL1 gene on chromosome 9

  • A part of chromosome 9 at band q34 (where the ABL1 proto-oncogene is located) breaks off.
  • A part of chromosome 22 at band q11 (where the BCR gene is located) breaks off.
  • These segments swap places (reciprocal exchange).
  • The result on chromosome 22 is the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, producing a constitutively active tyrosine kinase.
  • This altered chromosome 22 is called the Philadelphia chromosome.

Hack to remember: Amitabh Bachan favourite number is 9 (ABL1: chromosome 9)

questions.text: Bcr-abl1 fusion gene is seen in which of the following blood cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: ALL

  • Ph-like ALL, also known as BCR-ABL1-like ALL, is characterized by genetic lesions similar to Ph+ ALL, associated with IKZF1 (Ikaros) gene deletion

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not seen in patients with CML?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Low serum vitamin B12 levels

  • Basophilia is seen in CML as it is a myeloproliferative disorder.
  • In CML, serum B12 is high, not low, because increased granulocytes produce more transcobalamin I, which binds B12 and is responsible for DNA synthesis
  • Neutrophil Alkaline Phosphatase score is low in CML and it helps to differentiate from leukemoid reaction, where it is high. Low NAP score implies that post expiry date neutrophils that lost the ability to fight are circulating in blood stream. This explains the development of recurrent infections.
  • Normal bone marrow has a delicate network of reticulin fibers that support hematopoietic cells.In CML, as the disease progresses (especially toward accelerated phase or blast crisis), there is fibroblast stimulation by growth factors (PDGF, TGF-β) released from abnormal megakaryocytes and other marrow cells. This leads to increased deposition of reticulin and “reticulin fibrosis”.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old male presents with fatigue and early satiety. On examination massive splenomegaly is seen. Work up is shown below. What is next best investigation to be done in this case


	
		
			
			CBC
			
			
			Bone marrow aspiration report
			
		
		
			
			Hb: 10.5 g/dL

			TLC: 1.5 × 10⁵ /mm³

			Platelets: 4.0 × 10⁵ /mm³
			
			
			Myeloblasts: 2%, Promyelocytes: 15%, Myelocytes: 25%, Metamyelocytes: 20%

			Band forms & neutrophils: 18%, Basophils: 6%, Blasts + promyelocytes together: <10%, NAP score: low
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Peripheral blood FISH for BCR- ABL1

  • FISH detects the t(9;22) Philadelphia chromosome or BCR-ABL1 fusion gene without cell culture, so results are quicker than G-banding. It can be done directly from peripheral blood, so you avoid an invasive bone marrow procedure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with CML in chronic phase is started on imatinib. At diagnosis, bone marrow cytogenetics showed t(9;22)(q34;q11) in all metaphases. The treating physician now wants to assess whether he has achieved deep molecular remission. Which is the most appropriate investigation at this stage?

choices.text: Conventional karyotyping from bone marrow aspirate
FISH for BCR-ABL on peripheral blood
Quantitative RT-PCR for BCR-ABL transcript levels

questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: Quantitative RT-PCR for BCR -ABL transcript levels

Monitoring sequence in CML

  1. Hematologic response: CBC & peripheral smear (first 3 months)
  2. Cytogenetic response: Bone marrow karyotyping / FISH (at 6–12 months)
  3. Molecular response: Quantitative RT-PCR (qPCR) for BCR-ABL mRNA every 3–6 months thereafter
  • Deep molecular remission is defined as BCR-ABL ≤ 0.01% on the International Scale. qPCR is ~100–1000× more sensitive, detecting 1 leukemic cell among 10⁵–10⁶ normal cells.
  • Karyotyping and FISH detect cytogenetic remission but are less sensitive (~1–5% abnormal cells detection limit).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common presenting feature of CML?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Splenomegaly

  • CML often presents insidiously with symptoms related to splenic enlargement (fullness, early satiety, LUQ pain) and hypermetabolism (fever, weight loss, night sweats).

questions.text: 48-year-old man presents with fatigue, headache, and visual blurring. Examination reveals splenomegaly. CBC shows: Hb 9.8 g/dL, TLC 1.2 × 10⁵/µL, platelet count 650 × 10³/µL. Peripheral smear shows marked myeloid proliferation with occasional myeloblasts. Fundoscopy reveals retinal vein engorgement. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Leukapheresis

  • This patient with CML has symptomatic hyperleukocytosis (headache, visual symptoms, retinal vein engorgement).
  • Leukostasis is a medical emergency; immediate cytoreduction is needed. Leukapheresis rapidly lowers WBC count and relieves symptoms, while hydroxyurea can be added for ongoing control.
  • Imatinib is for definitive therapy but should be started after stabilization.
  • Allopurinol is for tumor lysis prevention, not acute management of leukostasis.

questions.text:
70-year-old male presents with fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and recurrent respiratory infections over the last 6 months. Examination reveals pallor and mild splenomegaly.

CBC shows:


	Hb: 9.8 g/dL
	TLC: 28,000/µL (Monocytes: 5,500/µL)
	Platelets: 110,000/µL


Peripheral smear shows monocytosis with occasional myelocytes and metamyelocytes. Bone marrow aspirate is hypercellular with increased monocytes, <20% blasts, and dysplastic features in granulocytic and megakaryocytic lineages.

Cytogenetic analysis is negative for the Philadelphia chromosome

Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: CMML

  • CMML (chronic myelomonocytic leukemia) is a myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by persistent monocytosis (>1 × 10⁹/L) and dysplasia in ≥1 myeloid line.
  • To diagnose CMML, CML must be excluded by ruling out BCR-ABL1 fusion (via PCR or FISH).
  • Juvenile Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia is ruled out based on age and absence of elevated Hb F.
